G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law implies into every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment, and G.L. c. 186, § 14 expressly prohibits a landlord from “directly or indirectly interfer[ing] with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts General Laws (“G.L.”) c. 186 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A an.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action for money damages arising out of a residential tenancy for property located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2 and G.L..proposition: Venue is proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 239, § 2 because the rental premises that are the subject of this action are located at 123 Maple Street in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

105 CMR 410.000.proposition: Defendant, as owner and landlord, is responsible for maintaining the Apartment and its electrical systems in compliance with the applicable state sanitary code, including without limitation 105 CMR 410.000, and for providing utilities and services required by law and by the lease.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Defendant’s violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 is independent of, and in addition to, any claim Plaintiff might have under the implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 239, or G.L. c. 93A; however, in this action Plaintiff asserts only the statutory cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: Defendant’s violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 is independent of, and in addition to, any claim Plaintiff might have under the implied warranty of habitability, G.L. c. 239, or G.L. c. 93A; however, in this action Plaintiff asserts only the statutory cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: The electrical defects in the bedroom and the resulting denial of use of that room constitute a defective condition and an interference with services required under the applicable housing laws and codes, including without limitation the minimum standards of fitness for human habitation under 105 CMR 410.000 and the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s separate opinion, not the majority, and it does not address electrical defects in a bedroom or denial of use of a room. While he discusses that landlords have an obligation, grounded in statutes and the State Sanitary Code, to meet minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and that tenants may get rent abatement based on Code violations, he expressly argues against a broad, undefined implied warranty of habitability beyond code-based standards. Thus, this text does not specifically support the proposition that electrical defects and loss of a bedroom constitute a defective condition and interference with required services under 105 CMR 410.000 and the implied warranty recognized by the court’s majority in Hemingway.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Under Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), a landlord may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment when the landlord’s actions or inactions “had a natural and probable consequence of interfering with the tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises,” even absent a specific intent to cause such interference.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion directly rejects an intent requirement and holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and where the landlord had the right to control the objectionable condition. The court explicitly states that the landlord’s conduct, not his intentions, is controlling, which matches the proposition that liability can arise absent a specific intent to interfere so long as the natural and probable consequence standard is met.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain a dwelling in conformity with the state sanitary code and to provide essential services can constitute an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service required by the State Sanitary Code—“constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment” under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling and that liability arises when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is interference with the tenant’s rights, squarely supporting the proposition that failure to maintain code-compliant essential services can be an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain a dwelling in conformity with the state sanitary code and to provide essential services can constitute an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that a landlord’s failure to repair serious sanitary, building, and fire code violations, including inadequate heat and hot water and vermin infestation, constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment. The court explains that such omissions, where the landlord has notice and fails adequately to correct them, are actionable under § 14, fitting squarely within the proposition that failure to maintain the dwelling and provide essential services can amount to unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14… Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment… it was inevitable that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment but does not state or apply any rule that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach. Instead, the court finds no breach because the landlord acted immediately after receiving notice and substantially remedied the conditions within two weeks, and it concludes there was "no evidence" of interference with quiet enjoyment. The case therefore illustrates circumstances where prompt repair avoids a breach, rather than affirming that unremedied substantial defects would constitute one.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. While these conditions were documented by the board of health pursuant to an inspection, a reinspection less than two weeks later indicated that substantially all the conditions had been satisfactorily addressed. The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explicitly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory quiet enjoyment provision) as covering a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary conditions and essential services, and holds that repeated, preventable flooding that renders an apartment non‑watertight and unsanitary, after notice, constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment. The opinion ties quiet enjoyment to serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the leased premises and affirms liability where the landlord recklessly allowed such conditions to persist, squarely supporting the proposition about substantial, ongoing habitability‑related defects breaching quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses what kind of landlord conduct constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and ties it to failure to repair known defects. It explains that negligent failure to repair defects of which the landlord has notice—such as problems affecting habitability—has repeatedly been deemed a § 14 violation, thus supporting the proposition that substantial, ongoing, unrepaired defects in essential services or habitability can breach quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case squarely concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court repeatedly frames the loss of heat and hot water as a ‘material breach of the warranty of habitability’ and analyzes only that doctrine, without invoking G.L. c. 186, §14 or using ‘quiet enjoyment’ terminology. Thus, while it supports that substantial, ongoing defects in heat and hot water constitute a material breach of habitability after notice, it does not establish that such conditions are a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. … We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case discusses breach of the Massachusetts statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the alleged interference here is criminal drug activity and resulting loss of use of common areas, not "substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services." The court’s quiet-enjoyment analysis focuses on the landlord’s failure to take measures to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful activity, not on physical or utility-related defects, and nowhere states that unremedied defects in habitability or essential services constitute a breach. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures…then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Mitchell v. U\u2011Haul Co. of Mass., 39.raw_text: Mitchell v. U‑Haul Co. of Mass., 396 Mass. 282 (1985)
Mitchell v. U\u2011Haul Co. of Mass., 39.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Mitchell v. U\u2011Haul Co. of Mass., 39.case_name: Fergione v. Director of the Division of Employment Security
Mitchell v. U\u2011Haul Co. of Mass., 39.support_reasoning: The case is an unemployment compensation decision about whether an employee left work voluntarily without good cause attributable to the employer under G.L. c. 151A, § 25(e). It does not involve landlord-tenant law, habitability, utilities, essential services, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition concerning substantial and ongoing defects in residential premises constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Mitchell v. U\u2011Haul Co. of Mass., 39.relevant_excerpt: "The factual dispute centered on whether Fergione should be denied benefits under G. L. c. 151A, § 25 (e) (1984 ed.), because she left her work 'voluntarily without good cause attributable' to Minuteman. A separation would not be voluntary under § 25 (e) if an employee’s reasons for leaving were of 'an urgent, compelling and necessitous nature.'"

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and ongoing defects affecting habitability, utilities, or essential services, when not remedied with reasonable promptness after notice, constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns rent control, security deposits, allocation of responsibility for heat and hot water, and calculation of damages for breach of the warranty of habitability. It does not discuss or apply G.L. c. 186, §14 or the doctrine of breach of quiet enjoyment, nor does it tie substantial defects or utility failures to a quiet enjoyment analysis. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about what constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: The opinion’s only discussion of conditions is in the context of habitability, not quiet enjoyment: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code… have existed in the tenant’s apartment… The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.” The court then addresses the measure of damages for breach of the warranty of habitability, not for breach of quiet enjoyment.
